Award.AwardTitle: Computational Prediction of Biological Networks in Microbes and Applications to Cyanobacteria
Award.AbstractNarration: The University of Georgia is awarded funds to develop a suite of computational tools in support of elucidation of metabolic and regulatory networks in microbial organisms. Using these computational tools in conjunction with experimental investigation, the team will predict and characterize a number of important metabolic networks and their associated regulatory networks in cyanobacteria. The outcome of these predictions will be wiring diagrams of the selected target networks. The computational elucidation of biological networks will rely mainly on information derived through comparative genome analyses and interpretation of microarray gene expression data. Currently over 40 cyanobacterial genomes have been sequenced or are in the process of being sequenced, providing a rich source of information for network elucidation. In addition, substantial microarray data has been or is being generated for various cyanobacterial organisms, which are or will be publicly accessible in the near future. Using such information, a number of computational tools will be developed to derive as much gene function and association information as possible, which will be then used as constraints in the elucidation of biological networks. These tools will include tools for (a) gene function prediction, (b) prediction of operons and regulons; (c) prediction of protein-protein and protein-DNA interactions; (d) mapping pathways/networks (possibly partial) across genomes; (e) prediction of functional modules that are conserved across multiple microbial organisms; and (f) prediction of the wiring diagrams of metabolic and regulatory networks. The target networks in cyanobacteria with sequenced genomes include (a) photosynthesis and its acclimation to different environmental factors, (b) nitrogen assimilation, (c) phosphorus assimilation, (d) carbon fixation, (e) iron assimilation and regulation and (f) osmolarity regulation. The predictions will be based on both public experimental data and data generated in this project. Each of the tools will provide a new and useful addition to the current pool of computational tools for microbial genome analysis and network elucidation. The computational tools can be used for network elucidation for microbial organisms in general as long as a target organism has its genome and some related genomes sequenced and has microarray gene expression data available relevant to the target networks. The comprehensive nature and the systemic approach of the planned prediction capability will provide a highly effective and transferable framework for microbial network elucidation in general. Other researchers can directly use this framework and the tools developed in this project in their own investigation of pathways and networks as all the prediction programs will be provided as open source. This project provides an ideal training ground for both undergraduate and graduate students to learn bioinformatics tool development and application for solving complex biological problems. New bioinformatics and genomics courses will be developed and taught based on the research results of this project. In addition, annual training workshops will teach interested microbiologists the use of the tools developed in this project and other related tools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cyanobacteria are among the oldest life forms on Earth and a very diverse group of organisms that inhabit in a broad range of ecological niches ranging from fresh water, soil to diverse open oceanographic areas, of which several species/strains contribute to a significant fraction of Earth’s primary production and the accompanying oxygen production while some others are globally significant contributors to nitrogen fixation. Although cyanobacteria have been studied for decades, our general understanding of this group of bacteria is limited compared to other well-studied organisms such as E. coli. For many of the most important biological processes in cyanobacteria such as carbon fixation, our knowledge about their molecular mechanisms is very limited. Providing possible network models, even rough ones, about these and other biological processes will prove to be highly valuable to cyanobacteria research.

 

The advent of microarray technology for gene expression measurement has revolutionized the biological sciences and generated enormous interest in the computational biology community and beyond as it provides a powerful tool for probing the detailed molecular mechanisms of complex biological systems and processes in a systematic manner. A particularly interesting aspect of such investigation is in prediction of how genes/proteins are wired together in metabolic and regulatory networks. We proposed in this proposal to develop a new framework along with a suite of new computational tools for elucidation of biological networks (including pathways) in microbes, based on (a) comparative genome analyses and (b) analyses of microarray gene expression data. Using this new framework and the tools, we plan to elucidate a number of biological networks that are important to the understanding of the key functions of cyanobacteria.

 

This five-year proposal has generated several innovative scientific activities and findings in the microbiology/cyanobacteria research fields. We have published more than 40 journal papers and nine book/book chapters in the relevant field, as shown in the following publication list. We have developed a dozen of software tools/databases in prediction of orthologous genes, non-coding RNA, co-regulated genes, operon and gene network, which significantly accelerates the prediction of biological networks from microbial genomic and transcriptomic data. We also have constructed and analyzed three key transcriptional regulation networks in the four representative cyanobacterial organisms, namely photosynthesis, nitrogen assimilation and osmoregulation, along with their cross-talk networks, which gives various new insights about cyanobacteria through our integrated experimental and computational studies.

 

This proposal also has significant impact on the educational training and outreach activities. The four postdocs were recruited to this project to work; three of them have got the faculty positions. Three graduate students received their Ph. D.s in part sponsored by this project. One undergraduate and two high-school students participated in research activities and generated interesting results in the project. The PI has co-written one book 'Computational Methods for Understanding Bacterial and Archaeal Genomes' with the World Scientific Publishing. About half of the chapters have used extensively material generated through this project. The PI also organized a summer bioinformatics program at UGA from July 20th - 24th in 2007, and organized and edited a Special Issue on 'Computational Challenges from Modern Biology' in Journal of Computer Science and Technology, which will include 16 review articles by leading bioinformatics researchers.
